newsitem.title: PERU: Peru government decrees new capital markets law.
newsitem.headline: Peru government decrees new capital markets law.

text.p: The Peruvian government decreed a new capital markets law Tuesday, drastically reducing the maximum stake the Lima Stock Exchange can hold in its own capital fund to 20 percent, down from 95 percent.

The Lima Stock Exchange previously controlled the majority of its income by holding a 95 percent stake in the market's Compensation and Liquidation Fund (Cavali), which holds the income generated by the exchange itself.
The exchange's president, Jose Luque, said on local radio the new law was drafted by officials who were unfamiliar with the workings of capital markets.
"When you are not an expert in a subject you should not meddle in it," he said, adding the existing law should not have been modified.
The new law, decreed under special legislative powers granted by Congress to the executive, also unifies the capital base required to operate as a brokerage on the exchange.

The law establishes that any brokerage with capital of 750,000 soles will be able to operate on the exchange, eliminating the previous system that had a range of lower capital requirements depending on the type of activity a brokerage carried out.
